## AdmiralMetabolic: My First Steps

[**AdmiralMetabolic**](https://pharmaverse.github.io/admiralmetabolic/)

An extension of the admiral package family for metabolic analysis in clinical trials

- Part of the pharmaverse ecosystem
- Provides ADaM dataset creation tools
- Specifically designed for metabolic endpoints

---

## What is AdmiralMetabolic?

**Purpose:**
- Standardizes metabolic data analysis workflows
- Follows CDISC ADaM standards
- Built on admiral's proven framework

**Target Users:**
- Clinical programmers
- Biostatisticians
- Data analysts in pharmaceutical industry

---

## My Contributions to AdmiralMetabolic

**Documentation & Vignettes**
- Wrote comprehensive vignettes for new users
- Improved existing documentation
- Added practical examples and use cases

**Code Review**
- Participated in pull request reviews
- Provided feedback on code quality
- Helped ensure consistency across the package

---

## What I Learned from AdmiralMetabolic

**Technical Skills:**
- Package documentation best practices
- Writing clear, user-focused vignettes
- Understanding CDISC standards better

**Process Skills:**
- How to review code effectively
- Working with GitHub workflows
- Communicating with package maintainers

---

## Contributing to dataviewR

[**dataviewR**](https://gsk-biostatistics.github.io/dataviewR/)

A package for creating interactive data visualization dashboards

- Developed by GSK Biostatistics
- Released on CRAN v1.0 (major milestone!)
- Makes data exploration accessible

---

## What is dataviewR?

**Core Features:**
- Interactive data tables
- Dynamic filtering and sorting
- User-friendly interface for non-programmers
- Built on modern web technologies

**Use Cases:**
- Clinical data review
- Safety monitoring
- Exploratory data analysis

---

## My Role in dataviewR

**Website Development**
- Created and maintained the pkgdown website
- Organized documentation structure
- Ensured professional presentation

**Documentation**
- Wrote detailed function documentation
- Created practical examples
- Added tutorials and how-to guides

---

## My Role in dataviewR (continued)

**Articles & Vignettes**
- Authored getting-started guides
- Created advanced usage examples
- Explained complex features clearly

**Result:**
- Package successfully released to CRAN v1.0
- Strong documentation foundation
- Ready for broad community use

---

## What I Learned Along the Way

**Technical Skills:**
- R package development workflows
- Documentation best practices (roxygen2, pkgdown)
- Unit testing with testthat
- Git and GitHub collaboration
- CDISC standards and pharma data structures

---

## What I Learned (continued)

**Soft Skills:**
- Communicating with diverse team members
- Taking and giving constructive feedback
- Working asynchronously across time zones
- Understanding user needs and perspectives
- Contributing effectively to team goals

---

## Key Takeaways

1. **Start Small** - Documentation and examples are valuable
2. **Be Patient** - Learning takes time
3. **Ask Questions** - Community is supportive
4. **Stay Consistent** - Regular small contributions add up
5. **Enjoy the Process** - It's rewarding to see your work used

---

## How YOU Can Get Started {.smaller}

**Finding Projects:**
- Look for "good first issue" labels on GitHub
- Check out pharmaverse packages
- Find projects you already use and love

**Types of Contributions:**
- Fix typos in documentation
- Add examples to functions
- Write vignettes or tutorials
- Report bugs with reproducible examples
- Improve test coverage

---

## How YOU Can Get Started (continued) {.smaller}

**Getting Comfortable:**
- Fork the repository and experiment
- Read the contributing guidelines
- Start with documentation before code
- Join community channels (Slack, discussions)

**Common Concerns:**
- "I'm not experienced enough" - Everyone starts somewhere
- "What if I make mistakes?" - That's what code review is for
- "I don't have time" - Even 30 minutes helps
- "My contribution is too small" - No contribution is too small!
